Harry Faversham.Action: Holds his gaze against Durrance but feels nervous and lacks natural ease.
Attempts to maintain his troops' discipline despite losing formation.
Engages playfully with friends, including teasing and laughing together in the barracks and on the street.
Responds good-naturedly to being held in a neck hold by Trench, showing tolerance and camaraderie.
Does not boast about personal accomplishments and avoids counting his victories.
Shows good rapport and camaraderie with fellow officers, engaging in light teasing and banter confidently.
Does not specify or count the number of drill wins, indicating perhaps a lack of focus on measurable achievements.
Watches Durrance uncomfortably, sensing something unspoken.
Watches Durrance uncomfortably, sensing he is holding something back.
Greets Colonel Sutch politely and acknowledges others' concerns despite own unease.
Seems uneasy and wants to share his concerns with Durrance but holds back.
Responds respectfully to family and friends, maintaining good-natured demeanor.
Greets Colonel Sutch politely, maintains composure in social setting, interacts respectfully with senior officers and his father.
Appears uneasy and distracted, seems hesitant to share what is on his mind with Durrance.
Shakes Dermod's hand warmly and embraces Ethne with tenderness and coyness, shares engagement news sensitively with friends.
Conceals the engagement news until the right moment, even from close friends, which causes some disappointment.
Warmly shakes Dermod's hand, confidently engages with Ethne and friends, manages delicate social situation tactfully by waiting for Ethne to be ready before revealing engagement.
Allows disappointment in Durrance without trying to fully smooth over feelings immediately, but maintains calm and lightens mood by joking with friends.
Takes Ethne in his arms to dance, smiling ironically, sharing a moment of intimacy and sincerity.
Tries to kiss Ethne while holding an umbrella over her, showing care and attentiveness.
Bends under the umbrella to keep Ethne dry, handing it to her to share protection.
Promises Ethne a wedding with all the traditional and romantic elements she desires, demonstrating sincere affection and attentiveness to her wishes.
Rushes to embrace Ethne when she walks away, showing emotional openness and connection.
Acknowledges Ethne’s sarcasm and lightness but maintains warmth and reassurance.
Feels quiet regret with Ethne’s forced lightness, showing emotional sensitivity.
Shares friendly competition with Durrance, engages in drinking game, shows good humor after losing by pouring whisky over his head.
Disregards Trench's loud and disruptive shouting during tender moment with Ethne, suggesting respect for his friend's privacy.
Displays physical agility and determination by leading in the cavalry obstacle course, racing skillfully and showing confidence in training.
Fails to identify whisky disguised as beer during the drinking contest, resulting in losing the race and conceding defeat.
Concedes defeat gracefully after the whisky mishap, showing good sportsmanship and self-awareness.
Laughs with others, hiding his mounting anxiety about the coming war.
Does not respond to Durrance’s comment about Ethne, remains silent and inwardly tormented.
Engages in a candid conversation with Durrance about fears and motivations for going to war, showing openness and empathy.
Feels ashamed of his own fear despite being friendly and supportive, indicating internal conflict but sincerity.
Hesitates to wake up his friend Durrance to talk, ultimately choosing not to disturb him, showing respect but also some emotional distance.
Hesitates and does not engage in conversation with Durrance in the morning despite wanting to talk, turns away and leaves quietly.
Questions the purpose of the military campaign and expresses doubt and fear about going to fight.
Buttons his uniform despite looking like he hasn't slept, indicates effort to fulfill duty even while struggling internally.
Smiles awkwardly but does not share his troubles with Willoughby, turns away instead of confiding in a friend.
Politely interrupts Colonel Hamilton to clearly state his intention to resign, showing respect despite tension.
Avoids eye contact with friend Willoughby when in distress, indicating emotional distance.
Firmly insists on resigning despite social pressures or expectations, showing sincerity to his own feelings.
Refuses to accept his commission and insists on resigning despite Colonel Hamilton's anger and disapproval
Does not respond to soldiers saluting him while leaving the barracks
Resigns his commission the day the regiment is sent to war, leaving without explanation.
Resigns his commission on the day the regiment is sent to war, without explaining his reasons or facing his comrades.
Takes decisive action by resigning rather than passively waiting, showing awareness of his own limits or convictions.
Sits quietly and seems reserved, reflecting on his own image in the window.
Interacts warmly and playfully with Ethne, engaging in light-hearted banter and humor.
Struggles to openly share difficult truths with Ethne, showing some emotional reserve or reticence.
Sits silently on the train in civilian clothes, looking stiff and reflective.
Is unable or unwilling to confide in Ethne about his true situation.
Engages gently with Ethne, playing along with the wedding rehearsal despite personal tension.
Expresses willingness to abandon his army career for Ethne, showing prioritization of love and shared future over personal ambition.
Hides the full truth about his resignation and his internal fears/guilt from Ethne.
Affirms his love and desire for Ethne's happiness, holds her close and comforts her.
Jokes and teases Ethne about the parcel and secret admirer, sharing light moments.
Shares with Ethne the painful truth behind the three white feathers, showing sincerity and vulnerability.
Expresses deep affection and prioritizes Ethne over others when reassuring her.
Admits resignation was not because of Ethne, but due to his own fear and unwillingness to fight.
Avoids directly answering Ethne's questions about his motives, causing her pain and distrust.
Accepts Ethne's rejection silently, taking back the engagement ring without protest.
Fails to reassure or comfort Ethne in her panic and hurt, remaining mostly silent or withdrawn.
Resigns from the army upon learning the regiment will be sent to war, showing inability to face conflict.
Avoids direct answers and is tormented by guilt, indicating internal conflict and lack of straightforwardness.
Admits honestly to Ethne that he would have resigned regardless of their engagement, showing some degree of self-awareness and honesty.
Gathers the four feathers very carefully, his eyes shining with tears, showing deep emotional connection and care.
Stares up at the ship among the cheering crowd like a ghost, feeling isolated but silently aware of his friends.
Gathers the four feathers very carefully, eyes shining with tears, showing emotional sensitivity and care.
Stares up at the troop ship as a ghost among cheering faces, separated and seemingly isolated from the victorious crowd.
Seeks conversation with his father despite tension and shame.
Buys newspapers from newsboys repeatedly to avoid confrontation, showing patience.
Forces money on a newsboy after being mistaken for a tramp, showing concern and generosity.
Urgently searches casualty list for his friends, shows concern and relief when they are safe.
Hides his disappointment awkwardly when Colonel Sutch arrives instead of Ethne, shows emotional restraint and sincerity.
Shows sincere concern about being seen and speaks honestly about not needing money.
Shares his deep emotional pain over being labeled a coward and the meaning of the white feathers from friends.
Remains introspective and somewhat withdrawn in conversation, not pushing for sympathy or connection.
Acknowledges his perceived lack of suitability for the profession, but shows clear self-awareness and curiosity about his own nature and fears.
Refuses financial help despite his hardships, showing pride and independence.
Holds onto the white feathers as symbols of shame and friendship, indicating emotional burden and fixation on past failure.
Engages in introspective questioning about cowardice, demonstrating thoughtful reflection but also possible self-doubt.
Does not act decisively or confidently to change his situation; remains withdrawn, driving himself mad with obsessive thoughts.
Plans a risky and dangerous journey to Egypt as a civilian despite great odds, showing determination and resolve.
Acknowledges low chances of success but still commits to his plan, showing realistic awareness and perseverance.
Chooses not to inform Ethne about his plans to protect her peace, indicating thoughtful consideration of others.
Seemingly acts out of anguish and guilt rather than strategic thinking, risking life impulsively.
Moves through the streets of Alexandria observing the local people and scenes carefully, showing a quiet attention to those around him.
Does not acknowledge or react to the group of urchin boys imitating his walk, ignoring their presence.
Sits quietly in the hotel lobby, nursing his drink and thoughtfully considering how to approach the group of English officers.
Moves through the crowded port and alleyways of Alexandria, observing details carefully but does not engage with his surroundings or people following him.
Sits quietly in the colonial hotel lobby, observing English officers and nursing his drink, appearing thoughtful and hesitant about approaching them.
Does not take immediate initiative or confidently engage with the English officers despite opportunity; rather waits and watches.
Fills the British Corporal's glass and engages him in conversation, showing attentiveness and camaraderie despite the corporal's drunken state.
Responds to the corporal's frustrations and listens without judgment, demonstrating tolerance and sincerity.
Smiles distractedly, quietly observes the desert landscape with awe, but does not interact with or show concern for the oppressed Dinka slavegirls or their harsh conditions.
Rides confidently at the front of the caravan through a harsh desert environment, calmly observing the landscape.
Smiles distractedly while Gustave discusses the harshness and dangers of the desert.
Intervenes to protect the Dinka slavegirl from Gustave’s violence by blocking him with his camel.
Maintains calm and steady gaze confronting Gustave, showing silent resistance to cruelty.
Feels a spark of hope in the lovers' defiance and freedom despite hardship.
Watches the intimate moment of Saadi and the slavegirl quietly, showing curiosity and respectful attention.
Faints to defend himself when attacked: shows vulnerability but no direct hostile or harsh behavior.
Rescues the Dinka slavegirl who leaves provisions behind for him.
Feels pity and looks away from Gustave's dead body.
Endures extreme hardship silently: sunburn, fever, painful injuries, yet presses on.
Cuts his camel's hide to drink its blood to survive, showing resourcefulness and determination.
Talks to himself in the desert, revealing vulnerability and humanizes him.
Accepts help from beggar boys and an Arab doctor despite cultural barriers, indicating openness and trust.
Wanders marketplace in Bedu robes, limping from ordeal, yet endures social rejection as passersby avoid him due to mistaken disease, showing tolerance of social misunderstanding.
Cuts the camel's hide and drinks its blood to survive in the desert.
Manages to stay alive through the harsh desert conditions despite fever and exhaustion.
Relies on beggar boys to guide him through the town.
Appears overwhelmed by illness and unable to communicate effectively (shakes head to doctor).
Watches his friends from a distance, longingly and silently, unable to face them yet due to shame or fear.
Does not react angrily or with hostility when local children mistake him for a leper and throw stones at him.
Hides from friends due to fear and lack of courage; unable to face them yet.
Observes the crocodile trap from a hidden vantage point, indicating patience and awareness.
Disguises himself and endures hardship to infiltrate the British camp.
Maintains patience and obedience while being examined by superiors despite difficult circumstances.
Sits with the coolies, shares their hardships despite being an officer.
Watches friends from afar rather than joining their mocking of the British officer.
Swallows rancid gruel silently alongside the Nubian.
Acknowledges Abou Fatma's warning with a silent gaze and a hesitant 'Shoukran,' showing respect despite language barrier.
Smiles at Abou Fatma and engages in friendly conversation about the feather and soldier's symbols.
Sits alone, silently enduring pain, reflecting inwardly but not reaching out for camaraderie or support.
Shows Abou Fatma the four white feathers, signaling he doesn't need help.
Offers Abou Fatma one shilling a day for help.
Can't help smiling as Abou Fatma walks away.
Shows the four white feathers to Abou Fatma, signaling a refusal of help but trying to assert capability.
Offers to pay Abou Fatma one shilling a day for help, attempting to negotiate assistance.
Smiles after Abou Fatma walks away, indicating a degree of confidence or resilience despite the rejection.
Observes the injured orderly and looks for Abou Fatma in the crowd, showing alertness and situational awareness.
Whispers to Abou Fatma to join desert detachment, showing respectful communication and trustworthiness.
Falls into line behind Abou Fatma without complaint, displaying patience and good-natured compliance.
Observes a coolie listening carefully to sounds in the gorge, showing attentiveness and concern for others' safety.
Insists on traveling with the desert detachment, showing determination and awareness of potential dangers.
Carefully observes his surroundings and notices a coolie listening to suspicious sounds, indicating vigilance and situational awareness.
Works with others to build a protective wall around the camp during a sandstorm
Shows concern about unknown signals and wants to investigate cautiously with Abou Fatma
Does not display overt friendliness or personal warmth in this excerpt; mostly focused and cautious
Observes closely, questions local guide about unfamiliar sound, does not accept easy answers.
Concentrates hard to locate the source of a suspicious whining noise in difficult conditions.
Checks if orderlies are watching before taking covert action, carefully signals companion to follow.
Shows caution and seeks to understand who the tribesman is signalling before acting aggressively.
Escapes the British camp stealthily at night to pursue enemy scouts with Abou Fatma, showing determination and focus.
Escapes from the enemy camp at night, evading pursuit despite gunfire.
Watches enemy scouts carefully and sets off in pursuit, showing strategic awareness and tracking skills.
Admits honestly to Abou Fatma that he is not a spy but a deserter, showing sincerity and openness.
Smiles and expresses gratitude ('Shoukran') to Abou Fatma after receiving a wise remark about soldiers running away.
Admits to being a deserter but continues to stay close to the enemy and observe their movements alongside Abou Fatma.
Carefully follows Nuer scouts' tracks and demonstrates patience and discretion in shadowing them through the desert.
Does not attempt to deceive Abou Fatma once the truth is realized, showing honesty and self-awareness.
Feels shame or hesitation at admitting to running away, possibly showing self-doubt.
His failure to initially keep up the pretence of being a spy may show difficulty in maintaining deception necessary for his covert role.
Lowers his eyes as he rides past the guards, showing quiet restraint and possibly respect or caution.
Follows Abou Fatma's lead without hesitation despite being in shock, indicating trust and willingness to cooperate.
Kneels beside fallen British soldiers, feels fear turning to anger, and slips on a bloodstained British uniform to blend in and survive.
Understands the Dervish Captain's instructions despite language barriers and quickly adapts by putting on a bloodstained British uniform to disguise himself.
Initially hesitates and his fear is apparent when faced with the threat of being executed among British dead soldiers.
Commands Abou Fatma to leave, showing firm control to protect his intent.
Sits among enemy warriors quietly observing, showing composure but no evident friendliness.
Commands Abou Fatma to leave him and wait at the gates with a firm 'Imshi,' showing decisiveness and command presence despite a tense situation.
Stares intently and calmly observes enemy movements and plans without showing panic or distraction.
Moves away from the suspicious Dervish Captain after noticing his gaze, showing awareness and tactfulness.
Charges and kills the Dervish Captain in self-defense during a dangerous encounter.
Charges through enemy ranks to warn British soldiers of danger despite personal risk, trying to prevent friendly fire.
Charges through enemy lines against orders, showing boldness and initiative.
Kicks horse and tries to weave out of charging horde, demonstrating quick reflexes and situational awareness.
Tolerates confusion as British soldiers mistake Dervish horsemen for their own, potentially endangering troops.
Runs towards the fighting in desperation to reach his friends.
Fights like a man possessed, cutting through enemies with intense aggression.
Cuts through the enemy ranks like a berserker, fighting with abandon despite previous doubts and fears.
Runs desperately towards the fighting to reach his friends, showing determination and courage.
Drops to his knees next to Castleton's body, protecting his friend's corpse from further abuse.
Runs through enemy ranks to rescue and protect Durrance, pinning him down to prevent further injury.
Watches in anguish as Durrance suffers, showing deep emotional concern.
Runs through enemy ranks pretending to be one of them, leaps on injured Durrance to pin him to the ground and protect him from further harm.
Keeps Durrance pinned until the enemy passes, then assesses his friend's condition carefully.
Confronts Willoughby to warn him, despite Willoughby's hostility
Does not show sympathy to Willoughby, appearing hardened after his experiences
Faces former allies despite rejection and disbelief
Tracks the British expedition across difficult terrain to deliver a critical warning, showing persistence and determination.
Confronts Willoughby with a soiled white feather symbolizing shame but without sympathy, indicating emotional resilience and matured seriousness.
Sends a man with a warning that was ignored, demonstrating a failure in communication impact despite his efforts.
Carries and supports his injured friend Durrance through a dangerous battlefield and mountain trail, showing physical and emotional care.
Cools Durrance's fevered face with a wet cloth and remains silently caring during Durrance's fevered questions.
Keeps his actions to help Durrance secret, indicating humility and absence of need for recognition.
Carries and helps injured Jack Durrance through a battlefield and up a steep mountain trail, showing physical endurance and care.
Remains silent when Jack Durrance murmurs questions in a feverish state, demonstrating controlled and resolute behavior under pressure.
Slips out of the crowd, horrified by the treatment of the corpse, showing empathy
Declines offered food initially but accepts and swallows rancid meat to sustain himself, showing respect and trust to Abou Fatma
Provokes Abou Fatma by questioning payment despite his concern, causing unintended offense
States he would sacrifice himself for a friend despite past conflicts, hopes to reciprocate friendship with Abou Fatma.
Offers more money than owed to Abou Fatma with a smile despite being scorned.
Pretends to be mad in the marketplace, engaging freely with strangers despite being rejected.
Seriously discusses and plans entering a prison known for death penalties, showing willingness to risk his life for a cause and understanding serious consequences.
Uses charm and boldness to engage with dangerous people like Abou Fatma and the Dervish warriors, demonstrating confidence and strategic thinking.
Pretends to be mad and stumbles through the market while pestering for money, a risky but deliberate tactic indicating cunning and resourcefulness.
Relies partially on superstition ('God protects the fool') to justify his risky behavior, which may indicate some impulsiveness or lack of cautious planning.
Keeps paying Abou Fatma more than owed despite disdain, showing persistence and possibly strategic generosity, but also could imply being manipulated.
Grins like a happy puppy while chewing thrown meat and plays his broken zither to amuse the warriors despite humiliation.
Snatches the Emir's scabbard and runs off wildly, provoking the warriors to chase him laughing.
Puts himself at physical risk by stumbling deliberately and allowing himself to be caned while protecting his face and pleading.
Mocks the warriors by walking around a ledge dangerously, performing and laughing with them despite being treated cruelly.

Deliberately stumbles after stealing the Emir's scabbard to provoke a chase and survive a dangerous situation by performing and maintaining balance on a 30-foot well ledge despite being provoked and threatened.
Plays a broken zither and behaves like a fool in front of hostile warriors, humiliating himself to manipulate their reactions.
Allows himself to be caned and taunted repeatedly, showing vulnerability but using performance and psychological tactics to maintain control of the situation.
Exhibits foolhardy behavior that can be perceived as reckless or eccentric, risking serious harm by provoking enemy warriors openly.
Feels overwhelming pity and dread for the crazed hag, is emotionally moved by her lament, showing compassion despite the grotesque scene.
Laughs at the hag while feeling emotional, creating a complex mix of mockery and sympathy.
Endures brutal physical torture without revealing his identity, singing softly and maintaining a composed, almost reverent attitude.
Grins at the Emir despite severe injury, sings softly in Arabic, showing resilience and a certain calm that commands respect and pity.
Endures great physical pain silently without lashing out or showing anger towards captors.
Surprises Trench by coming to rescue him despite great personal risk, showing loyalty and care.
Uses ironic good humor in a dire situation to lighten the mood and connect with Trench.
Keeps plans discreet by whispering and warning to keep voice down, showing trustworthiness and prudence.
Offers money to bribe guards to help rescue, indicating resourcefulness and sincere intent to aid friend.
Maintains ironic good humor despite pain and harsh circumstances.
Has devised a plan to rescue a prisoner using bribery, arranging a contact with camels and provisions.
Carries significant money and uses it strategically to influence guards.
Returns to a hostile environment despite great personal risk.
Watches the boat and understands the dangers of crocodiles, acknowledges his own recklessness and bravery.
Admits openly 'I didn't think of much when I came,' indicating impulsiveness or lack of prior planning.
Cradles his weak friend Trench in his arms, tries to rouse him despite danger, protects him from harm
Looks after his friend Trench by brushing the wet hair from his face and promising to get him to Wilton's.
Watches with emotional detachment as Ibrahim is attacked by a crocodile and looks back at his feverish friend Trench.
Watches calmly and attentively as Ibrahim is attacked by crocodile; appears observant and steady in a dangerous situation.
Looks back at his feverish friend Trench with concern, showing awareness and care in difficult circumstances.
No direct action in this excerpt indicating capability or skill; largely observed reacting.
Chews food to soften it and feeds it to the incapacitated Trench with human tenderness despite harsh conditions.
Defends Trench fiercely from other prisoners, biting a prisoner who tries to harm him.
Begging prison guard Idris in Arabic for the return of food to feed Trench, showing humility and caring.
Elbowing and head-butting other prisoners savagely to get hold of food, causing physical harm to others.
Fights fiercely and with primal savagery to secure food and protect an ally in prison conditions.
Shows resourcefulness and empathy by feeding Trench by chewing meat for him and fending off attackers despite his own injuries.
Begging violently and enduring whipping to retrieve a scrap of food, showing persistence but also desperation.
Pleads sincerely for food for his friend despite his own weakness and desperation.
Carefully examines the food to ensure there is enough left for Trench, showing concern for others even when starving.
Returns coins to the Arab boy because money alone can't secure food, demonstrating practical trust and honesty.
Gives coins to Arab boy, thanks him sincerely, showing appreciation and goodwill.
Watches Arab boy leave, silently missing human contact, indicating loneliness and longing for connection.
Pours water over Trench's face to revive him, showing care and concern for a friend.
Encourages Trench by telling him he’ll get through his suffering, expressing hope and support.
Nods in sympathy at Trench's despair, unable to argue against his pain but offering silent support.
Communicates clearly and effectively with the Arab boy, giving commands in Arabic and showing leadership in a tense situation.
Scrambles away as Idris approaches menacingly, reverting to a 'bestial state', showing fear and lack of confidence in confrontation.
Cares for Trench by pouring water over his face and tries to encourage him despite both being in poor condition, demonstrating empathy and resilience.
Struggles internally with his own pain and is unable to argue effectively with Trench, showing emotional difficulty but maintains supportive presence.
Pats the Arab boy on the shoulder and asks him to thank Abou Fatma and pray for them, showing empathy and sincerity.
Gives TRENCH the poison to avoid suffering, showing compassion and trustworthiness.
Swallows the rest of the poison himself, sharing the burden with TRENCH and showing solidarity and friendship.
Grins at Trench and suggests giving the enemy one last night of hell, charging first into battle with him.
Despite being thought dead and burdened under corpses, subtly ensures his friend Trench is thrown overboard first to protect him.
Swallows poison and then charges shoulder first into massing prisoners, showing courage and decisiveness.

Survives being presumed dead and manages to extricate himself through corpses to locate and protect his unconscious friend, demonstrating calmness, situational awareness, and physical skill under extreme conditions.
Remembers TRENCH even in life-threatening situation, swims up to save him.
Holds unconscious TRENCH in his arms while swimming through dangerous crocodile-infested water.
Holds TRENCH tightly while being swept through dangerous currents and rocks, showing care and protectiveness.
Holds tightly to Trench while being swept through dangerous, jagged rocks by the river current, demonstrating presence of mind and physical capability in a life-threatening situation.
Engages in extremely violent and brutal combat with IDRIS, showing uncontrolled rage and mercilessly attacking him.
Takes out the fourth feather and gives it back to Ethne despite personal attachment.
Acknowledges Ethne's support and shares credit with her.
Visits Ethne after returning home despite delay and possible hurt feelings.
Engages in a sincere and dignified conversation attempting to preserve the memory of their relationship.
Returns the fourth feather, symbolizing acceptance and closure; demonstrates quiet dignity and emotional strength.
Admits he did not accomplish feats alone, showing humility and realistic self-assessment.
Delayed visit to Ethne, suggesting possible emotional hesitation or poor timing in handling personal relationships.
Engages in sincere, meaningful conversation acknowledging past mistakes and emotional complexity, showing emotional intelligence and interpersonal tact.
Takes Ethne in his arms when she tries to leave, showing mutual comfort despite tension.
Maintains polite but distant behavior with Ethne, walking several feet apart, indicating emotional reserve or guardedness.
Chooses to visit Jack and leaves a note, indicating caring and concern for a friend.
Thanks his friend Jack Durrance for standing by him despite the tension around the feather incident.
Shows sensitivity by understanding Ethne's choice to give them time alone rather than join immediately.
Expresses regret about emotional distance with friend, indicating sincerity and concern.
Pours two perfect glasses of Scotch carefully and manages the social interaction with his friend thoughtfully and respectfully.
Reads the unspoken tension in conversation and responds with awareness, showing emotional intelligence.
Maintains polite and considerate dialogue despite underlying distress and complex emotions.
Leaves the conversation without fully addressing the silence and unresolved tension.
Reassures Durrance gently, acknowledges his efforts sincerely, and recalls his bravery with affection.
Admits he was never a real soldier like Durrance; shows some self-doubt about his military competence.
Reassures his friend Durrance gently, showing emotional intelligence and calmness.
Observes and recalls the battlefield actions of his friends with affection and accurate detail.
States he was never acknowledged or reinstated by the British Army, implying a lack of formal military recognition or authority.
Affectionately tells Durrance he was always the better soldier despite rivalry.
Smiles but doesn't openly engage when discussing Ethne's attention, showing some reservation or emotional restraint.
Acknowledges being outperformed in a cavalry charge but maintains good-natured composure and affectionately compliments a more skilled soldier.
Smiles and listens attentively in a social situation involving rivals and romantic interests, showing emotional intelligence and self-awareness.
Passively allows others to prepare him meticulously for his wedding, showing reliance on others rather than independent decisiveness or confidence.
Smiles at the other guests despite being distracted and hopeful about Durrance showing up.
Mockingly interacts with General Feversham with light humor, creating a friendly atmosphere.
Smiles politely at guests despite being distracted and disappointed when his friend Durrance does not appear.
Engages in light banter with General Feversham and Colonel Sutch while being dressed in uniform, showing confidence and composure.
Mocks the situation lightly by joking about being declared dead, indicating awareness and social skill.
Notices the map of Africa during the briefing, showing situational awareness and focus.
Remains quiet and observant during the intense training and briefing sessions without showing panic or frustration.
Stares silently and inwardly during the briefing, showing internal conflict but remaining composed.
Laughs with other officers, masking his anxiety about the coming war.
Does not voice his fear or doubts openly, showing hesitation to express vulnerability or possibly uncertainty.
Contemplates the possibility of not returning, demonstrating awareness of danger and gravity of mission.
Decides to resign from the army after thoughtful consideration linked to his personal values and love for Ethne, demonstrating self-awareness and decisive action.
Hides the full truth from Ethne about his resignation and true feelings, showing a lack of transparency and potential insecurity.
Expresses love and commitment clearly and thoughtfully, proposing to help with the farm, indicating adaptive planning and emotional intelligence.
Hesitates and hides his eyes from Ethne when questioned about his certainty, reflecting inner doubt or lack of full confidence.
Steadies his camel skillfully to block Gustave from whipping the slavegirl, matching Gustave's moves with equal skill and confidence.
Maintains calm and unflinching eye contact with an aggressive adversary, intimidating him into backing down.
Drags a dead man into the stable after killing him in battle, showing resilience and a grim sense of duty.
Despite hostile surroundings, calmly gives alms to beggars, demonstrating generosity and kindness even in dire circumstances.
Entrusts Abou Fatma with critical information to warn the British camp of an ambush, showing trustworthiness and concern for others’ safety.
Breaks through the Dervish line and rides towards a lone British soldier to warn or assist.
Slits the dead horse's belly to free himself despite the danger, showing determination to survive and possibly continue helping others.
Breaks through the enemy line, drives his horse towards a British soldier at the camp perimeter, acting under pressure.
Slits the dead horse's belly with his knife to free himself after being pinned down, showing resourcefulness and presence of mind.
Is pinned under a dead horse after a gunshot, indicating vulnerability in combat but not necessarily incompetence.
Is described as determined but not reckless, showing a capacity to plan to find comrades before returning.
Does not communicate plans or whereabouts to others, leaving friends and loved ones uncertain and worried.
Slips out of a hostile crowd horrified, yet relieved to avoid danger.
Squats beside Abou Fatma and calmly engages in conversation to gain information.
Refuses food offered initially, then accepts rancid meat and swallows it to maintain composure.
Provokes Abou Fatma about payment, testing his reaction to get truthful information.
Sings softly in Arabic despite severe injuries, showing mental resilience and presence of mind.
Grins at the Emir while severely wounded, demonstrating defiance and psychological strength.
Endures extreme physical pain and mistreatment without breaking down, illustrating strong will and endurance.
Watches the prisoners and the grim scene quietly, accepting the harsh reality without complaint.
Responds to Trench's grim comment with a light and sincere tone, showing understated courage and trust.
Smiles softly and speaks with sincerity about the feather symbolizing himself and its inevitable return, indicating trust and good-naturedness.
Smiles affectionately at Trench, determined to help despite physical difficulty.
Shares lighthearted banter and laughter with Trench amid hardship.
Calmly guides and supports TRENCH through a dangerous river crossing, encouraging him and helping him to safety.
Attempts to help IDRIS after he surprises Harry by attacking him and holds Harry underwater, but Harry defends himself with force.
